qas.question: From where does the color red in blood come from?
What causes the color of hematite and red ochre?
Why does a sky turn red when the evening comes?
What pigment is responsible for the color of leaves in fall?
What is the Grand Canyon considered a form of?
What effect is responsible for the red color of Mars?
What are the pigments in the red sky called?
What percent of the population has red lips?

context: In nature, the red color of blood comes from <a0_0>hemoglobin<a0_0/>, the <a1_0><b5_0>iron<a1_0/>-containing protein<b5_0/> found in the red blood cells of all vertebrates. The red color of the Grand Canyon and other geological features is caused by hematite or red ochre, both forms of <a2_0><b6_0>iron oxide<b6_0/><a2_0/>. It also causes the red color of the planet Mars. The red sky at sunset and sunrise is caused by an optical effect known as <a3_0><b7_0>Rayleigh scattering<b7_0/><a3_0/>, which, when the sun is low or below the horizon, increases the red-wavelength light that reaches the eye. The color of autumn leaves is caused by pigments called <a4_0><b8_0>anthocyanins<b8_0/><a4_0/>, which are produced towards the end of summer, when the green chlorophyll is no longer produced. <b9_0>One to two percent<b9_0/> of the human population has red hair; the color is produced by high levels of the reddish pigment pheomelanin (which also accounts for the red color of the lips) and relatively low levels of the dark pigment eumelanin.
